section.heading: Maintenance.
section.text: An owner of a public pool or spa shall ensure that:

para.text: An inspection of the pool or spa and related facilities is made at least once a week by the operator for the purpose of maintaining the pool or spa in compliance with this chapter;
The pool or spa and its related facilities are maintained in a safe, clean, and orderly condition;
A broken, damaged, or malfunctioning fixture is promptly repaired or replaced; and
The pool or spa is left in a safe condition when closed for the season.
First Aid and Lifesaving Equipment. An owner shall ensure that:
A recreational pool is provided with:
A first aid kit as recommended by the American Red Cross;
A face mask for CPR;
Disposable medical grade examination gloves;
A bloodborne pathogen control kit;
A backboard designed for medical emergency use that is equipped with straps and head immobilizer;
A light, strong rescue pole not less than 10 feet long; and
A rescue tube designed for lifesaving for each required lifeguard;
Except as set forth in §A(3) of this regulation, a public spa is provided with the safety equipment required in §A(1)(a)—(e) of this regulation;
A semipublic spa is provided with the safety equipment required in §A(1)(a)—(d) of this regulation; and
A semipublic pool is provided with a:
Light, strong rescue pole not less than 10 feet long; and
Ring buoy or similar approved floatation device with an attached throwing rope measuring 50 feet in length or 1-1/2 times the width of the pool, whichever is longer.
Telephone. An owner shall ensure that, in case of an emergency, a telephone is available within the pool or spa enclosure to individuals using a public pool or spa that:
Can directly reach a 911 emergency service without the use of a coin and without connection to an internal switchboard;
Is posted with:
The names and phone numbers of the nearest available police, fire, and ambulance or rescue unit; or
911 or with any numbers necessary to reach a 911 emergency service center directly; and
Is posted with the name and location of the pool or spa facility.
Lifeguard Chair.
An owner shall ensure that a recreational pool is equipped with lifeguard chairs in compliance with the American National Standard for Public Swimming Pools.
An owner may use a deck-level lifeguard chair in a designated area on the deck adjacent to shallow water instead of an elevated lifeguard chair.
Lifeguards.
An owner of a public pool shall comply with:
Local codes requiring lifeguards if the requirements of the local codes are stricter than the requirements set forth in §D(2)—(5) of this regulation; or
§D(2)—(5) of this regulation if no local codes exist, or if the local codes requiring lifeguards are not as strict as the requirements of §D(2)—(5) of this regulation.

Except as set forth in §D(1) and (3) of this regulation, an owner of a recreational pool shall have at least one lifeguard on duty on the deck observing the pool while an individual is in the pool, and shall have at the pool:
Lifeguards who are appropriately trained and certified for the type of facility and activity in the pool;
A sufficient number of lifeguards so that a lifeguard is on duty for each group of 50 individuals, or fraction thereof, in the pool; and
In addition to the number of lifeguards required in §D(2)(b) of this regulation, additional lifeguards on duty if:
The shape, dimensions, layout, use, activities, or features of the pool create potential safety hazards;
The vision of the required lifeguard or lifeguards is obstructed;
The capabilities of the individuals using the pool are substandard; or
Another condition exists that compromises the ability of a lifeguard to monitor the pool.

An owner may use a lifeguard on the deck of a swimming pool to monitor an adjacent wading pool, but if a wading pool is the only pool at a facility or if the wading pool cannot be observed from the deck of the swimming pool, the owner shall ensure that lifeguards are provided at the wading pool in accordance with §D(1) and (2) of this regulation.
In addition to meeting the other requirements of this chapter, an owner or operator of a facility specified in the following paragraphs shall ensure that a:
Limited public-use pool has water safety supervision for pool activities in compliance with Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Child care center has water safety supervision for pool activities at a child care center in compliance with COMAR 07.04.02.41; and
Youth camp has water safety supervision for pool activities at a youth camp in compliance with COMAR 10.16.06.
The owner may only use or employ a lifeguard who holds a valid lifeguard certification from:
The American Red Cross;
The Boy Scouts of America, not including a lifesaving merit badge;
The Young Men's Christian Association;
Ellis and Associates' National Pool and Waterpark Lifeguard Training; or
An organization that has a lifeguard training program equivalent to the American Red Cross lifeguard training.

Except as set forth in §D(1) and (3) of this regulation, an owner of a semipublic pool that has a water surface area greater than 2,500 square feet or that is part of a multiple pool facility within one enclosure that has a combined water surface area greater than 2,500 square feet shall ensure that at least one lifeguard is on duty on the deck observing a pool in the ratio of one guard per 50 individuals in the water:
During the peak seasonal use of the pool from Memorial Day to Labor Day; and
During the use of an indoor, heated pool throughout the entire year.
CPR and First-Aid Personnel. Except at a semipublic spa, an owner of a recreational pool, public spa, and a limited public use pool shall ensure that:
When the pool or spa is open for use, an individual is present and on-site, holding a valid certification for:
Infant/child/adult or professional rescuer cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR); and
First aid; and
The CPR and first aid certifications of the individual required in §E(1) of this regulation are from:
A national organization offering certification in CPR or first aid, such as the:
American Red Cross;
American Heart Association; or
National Safety Council;
The Emergency Medical Services; or
An organization that has a certification program in CPR or first aid that is approved by one of the organizations listed in §E(2) of this regulation.
Safety Signs. An owner of a public pool or spa shall ensure that:

The size, color, design, application, symbol, and visual layout of a safety sign is in compliance with the ANSI Z-535 series of standards for Safety Signs and Colors as referenced in American National Standard for Public Spas;
A spa safety sign is posted in a permanent location adjacent to a spa in compliance with the American National Standard for Public Spas;
The spa safety sign includes the user load of the spa;
A chemical warning sign is posted at the entrance door to a chemical storage area and includes the text "Caution! Chemical Storage Area";
A chemical vat, feeder, pump, and line is labeled to identify the chemical in use;
A chlorine gas warning sign reading "Danger—Chlorine Gas" is posted at the entrance to a chlorine gas feed room and storage area;
Other warning, health advisory, and safety signs are posted if necessary to protect the public health and safety, for example, "Danger! No Diving In Shallow Water";

A semipublic pool or public spa that does not have a lifeguard on duty has a conspicuous sign posted adjacent to entrances to the pool or spa reading "WARNING; NO LIFEGUARD ON DUTY. YOUR OWN RISK.</U> WITHOUT ADULT SUPERVISION."; and
House rules are posted at the entrance to a pool or spa.
A person may not act as or perform the duties of a public pool or spa operator without a pool and spa operator certification card issued by the Secretary as required in §§B and G of this regulation.
The Secretary shall issue a 3-year public pool and spa operator certification card only to an individual 16 years old or older who has:

Completed a 14-hour approved public pool and spa operator's course or a course offered by the Secretary with a minimum grade of 70 percent on an approved written examination given following the completion of that course; or
Presented proof of previous certification and has:
Completed an approved 4-hour refresher course; or
Passed a challenge exam offered by the Secretary.
The Secretary may summarily suspend a pool and spa operator's certification if the operator does not comply with Regulation .43 of this chapter.

Hearing for Summary Suspension. In the case of the summary suspension of certification pursuant to §C of this regulation, the Secretary shall provide the certification card holder with written notice of the suspension and an opportunity for a hearing pursuant to State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
To preserve the right to a hearing, the certification card holder shall contact the Secretary within 30 days of the receipt of the notice of the suspension.
The Secretary shall recognize a pool and spa operator certification as valid throughout the State.
The Secretary shall issue a 3-year limited public-use pool operator certification card to an individual 16 years old or older who has completed:
An approved 4-hour limited public-use pool operator's course and passed an approved written examination with a minimum grade of 75 percent following completion of the course; or
The requirements of §B of this regulation.

An individual who possesses a public pool and spa operator certification card may perform the duties of a public pool and spa operator at a limited public-use, recreational, and semipublic pool and public spa. An individual who possesses a limited public-use pool operator certification card may perform the duties of a limited public-use pool operator only at a limited public-use pool.

section.heading: Approval of Operator's Course.
section.text: The Secretary shall approve a pool and a spa operator's course based on the following criteria:

para.text: An approved course shall cover general aspects of public pool and spa operation including:
Applicable regulations;
Disease prevention;
Disinfection;
Filtration;
Circulation system components;
General pool and spa equipment;
Operation and maintenance of equipment;
Water chemistry;
Water testing;
Record keeping;
General pool and spa chemicals;
Chemical handling;
Waste water disposal;
Safety;
Sanitation; and
Other pertinent topics as specified by the Secretary; and
An approved course shall be taught by an individual who has demonstrated to the Secretary:
Expertise in the operational aspects listed in §A of this regulation, as evidenced by combined work experience, training, and formal education; and
Successful completion of an approved public pool and spa operator's course.

section.heading: Pool and Spa Operation.
section.text: An owner shall ensure that a certified pool and spa operator:

para.text: Is on-site at all times when a recreational pool is open;
Is available at a semipublic pool, public spa, and at a limited public-use pool for performance of all requirements of this chapter and is able to respond to operational problems within:
30 minutes when not available on-site; or
If a contractual certified pool and spa operator, 2 hours when not available on-site;
Measures and records, or supervises and verifies the measurement and recording of, all information required in Regulation .46 of this chapter;
Performs all duties related to the operation of a pool or spa as required in this chapter;
Cleans the filtration system when the filter pressure differential reaches a level specified by the equipment's manufacturer or as specified below:
High rate sand filters at 15 psi;
Rapid rate sand filters at 8 psi;
Cartridge filters at 10 psi;
Pressure diatomaceous earth filters at 10 psi; and
Vacuum diatomaceous earth filters at 15 inches of mercury;
Maintains disinfection residuals according to Regulation .44 of this chapter;
Maintains water chemistry according to Regulation .45 of this chapter; and

Adds a nonstabilized oxidizer into the pool or spa water equivalent to an amount of free chlorine equal to at least 10 times the measured combined chlorine residual plus sufficient free chlorine to oxidize the ammonia and nitrogenous compounds in the water, on a recommended schedule of once per week for a pool and once per day for a wading pool and for a spa.

section.heading: Disinfection of a Pool and Spa.

para.text: An owner or operator of a public pool or spa shall ensure that a disinfectant or combination of disinfectants is added to the water automatically through an approved chemical feeder to maintain continuously a residual level as specified below:
Free chlorine shall be between:
1.5 ppm and 10.0 ppm in pools for swimming and diving and water recreational attractions;
3.0 ppm and 10.0 ppm in pools for wading or therapy; and
4.0 ppm and 10.0 ppm in spas;
The maximum amount of combined chlorine shall be 0.2 ppm for all pools and spas;
Total bromine shall be between:
3.0 ppm and 8.0 ppm in pools for swimming and diving and water recreational attractions; and
4.0 ppm and 8.0 ppm in spas and in pools for wading or therapy;
For pools and spas using copper and silver ions as a secondary disinfectant in conjunction with chlorine or bromine as a primary disinfectant:
Copper ions shall be between 0.2 ppm and 1.0 ppm;
Silver ions may not exceed 0.05 ppm;
Free chlorine in combination with copper and silver ions shall be between:
0.5 ppm and 10 ppm in pools for swimming and diving and water recreational attractions; and
1.5 ppm and 10.0 ppm in spas and in a pool for wading or therapy; and
Total bromine in combination with copper and silver ions shall be between:
1.0 ppm and 8.0 ppm in pools for swimming and diving and water recreational attractions; and
3.0 ppm and 8.0 ppm in spas and pools for wading or therapy;
For pools and spas using an ozone generator, the maximum amount of ozone measured 2 inches above the water surface shall be 0.1 ppm;
For pools using PHMB, the minimum level of PHMB shall be 30 ppm; and
For pools and spas using an ultraviolet light/hydrogen peroxide system, the minimum level of hydrogen peroxide shall be 20 ppm.
An owner or operator shall ensure that for public pools and spas using cyanuric acid or a similar chlorine stabilizer, the cyanuric acid is maintained between 30 ppm and 100 ppm.
An owner or operator of a public pool or spa may not use:
PHMB in a pool or spa that uses jets or sprays;
PHMB in conjunction with any halogen compound or ozone;
Cyanuric acid in conjunction with a bromine compound or in an indoor pool or spa; or
An ultraviolet light/hydrogen peroxide system in conjunction with a diatomaceous earth filter.

section.heading: Water Chemistry of a Pool and Spa.

para.text: An owner or operator shall ensure that the water chemistry of a public pool or spa is maintained according to the following requirements:
The pH of the water is maintained between 7.2 and 7.8;
The total alkalinity of the water is maintained between 60 ppm and 180 ppm;
The calcium hardness of the water is maintained between 150 and 400 ppm;
The Langelier Saturation Index of the water is maintained between -0.5 and +0.5 as calculated by:
The Langelier Saturation Index formula: Langelier Saturation Index = pH + TF + CF + AF - 12.1 where: TF = temperature factor, CF = calcium hardness factor, and AF = alkalinity factor, and
The following factor table:
The amount of total dissolved solids is maintained so that it does not exceed 1,500 ppm, except for a salt water pool where the total dissolved solids may not exceed 3,000 ppm;
The amount of dissolved metals is maintained so that it does not exceed the following levels:
Iron, 0.3 ppm,
Manganese, 0.3 ppm, and
Copper, 1.3 ppm; and

The water clarity is maintained so that either a 6 inch seechi disc placed in the deepest part of a pool or spa or the main drain is clearly visible and sharply defined when observed from the side of the pool or spa.
An owner or operator shall ensure that:
Water additives and treatment chemicals are used according to manufacturers' instructions; and
When chemicals are added directly to a pool or spa, no one is allowed in the water until the chemicals are dissolved and diffused throughout the pool or spa.
An owner or operator shall ensure that the water temperature for a heated public pool or spa does not exceed:
88°F for a pool;
104°F for a spa; and
96°F for a therapy pool.

section.heading: Operating Records Required.
section.text: An operator shall maintain operating records on a form provided by the Secretary or an equivalent form and shall:

para.text: Except as provided in §B of this regulation, record the information required in §C(1)—(3) of this regulation in 2-hour intervals for a recreational pool and for a public spa, and three times per day for a limited public-use and semipublic pool and record the information required in §C(4)—(9) of this regulation a minimum of three times per day for a public pool and spa, beginning 1/2 hour before opening;
For a public pool or spa where an approved automatic controller is used, record the information required in §C of this regulation:
A minimum of three times per day in conformance with the following schedule:
The first recording of the day shall be made 1/2 hour before the pool or spa opens;
The second recording shall be completed between 12 p.m. and 2 p.m.; and
The final recording shall be completed 2 hours before closing; and
More frequently if required by the Secretary due to conditions such as high bather load, high temperatures, bright sunlight, or inadequate water quality;
Record the following information in the intervals required in §§A and B of this regulation:
Disinfectant residual;
Combined chlorine level, if chlorine is used;
pH;
Water clarity;
Water temperature, if heated;
Flow rate;
Filter influent pressure and effluent pressure;
Pump vacuum; and
Total number of bathers;
Record in 1-week intervals for a public pool and in 1-day intervals for a public spa:
Total alkalinity level;
Calcium hardness level; and
Cyanuric acid level, if used;
Record daily for a public pool or spa:
The time of filter backwash or cleaning;
An injury or accident at the pool or spa;
Chemicals added to the water; and
Malfunctioning or broken equipment;
Date and sign each record sheet;
Record the results of the following inspections in the specified intervals to complete a Pool and Spa Entrapment Hazards Checklist:
Daily check before the facility is open to verify that:
Drain covers, vacuum fitting covers, skimmer equalizer covers, and any other suction outlet covers are in place, secure, and unbroken;
Skimmer baskets, weirs, lids, flow adjusters, and suction outlet lines are free of any blockage;
Inlet and return covers or fittings are in place, secure, and unbroken;
Safety warning signs are in place around the pool or spa, including emergency instructions and phone numbers; and
On/off switches for pumps are clearly labeled and the location of the pumps is clearly identified; and
Check all information required in §G(1) of this regulation before filling a pool or spa with water, after periodic maintenance, and after pool or filter cleaning procedures;
Keep the records on the premises for a minimum of 3 years; and
Submit the records to the Secretary upon request.
In order to comply with the requirements of Regulation .46 of this chapter, an owner shall ensure that:
One or more of the following for measuring the disinfectant level is used:

A chlorine or bromine test kit that is the DPD (diethyl-p-phenylene diamine) reagent system for measuring free and combined chlorine or total bromine with an indicator range from 0.0 to 10.0 ppm or with procedures for performing a dilution test to achieve readings up to 10.0 ppm;
An ozone test kit that is the indigo trisulfonate method for measuring ozone with an indicator range from 0.0 to 1.0 ppm;
A copper test kit that is accurate to within +/- 0.1 ppm for measuring copper;
A PHMB test kit with an indicator range from 0.0 ppm to 75 ppm; or
A hydrogen peroxide test kit that is the DPD reagent system with an indicator range from 0.0 to 40 ppm;
A phenol red test is used to measure pH with an indicator range from at least 7.0 to 8.0;
An alkalinity titration test is used to measure alkalinity as milligrams per liter calcium carbonate;
An EDTA (ethylenediamine-tetraacetate) hardness test is used to measure calcium hardness as milligrams per liter calcium carbonate; and
A cyanuric acid test kit with an indicator range from 0 to 100 ppm is used if cyanuric acid is used in the pool or spa.
In order to comply with the requirements of Regulation .46 of this chapter, an owner may monitor:
Chlorine and bromine residuals by measuring the oxidation-reduction potential (ORP) of the water before the disinfectant injection point; and
The pH with a pH meter.
If an ORP or pH meter is used, an owner shall ensure that:
Periodic calibration is performed on these instruments to assure accurate measurements; and
Manual measurements are performed on a daily basis.

section.heading: Sanitary Quality of Water.
section.text: Although routine testing is not required, an owner shall ensure that the water in a public pool or spa:

para.text: Has a coliform bacteria level of less than 1 coliform per milliliter; and
Is free of pathogenic organisms.

section.heading: Chemical Handling and Storage.
section.text: An owner shall ensure that a:

para.text: Material safety data sheet for a potentially hazardous chemical is available to the operator;
Chemical is handled, used, stored, and disposed of in accordance with the material safety data sheet and all applicable federal, State, and local codes; and
Chemical is stored in a chemical storage area which is in compliance with Regulation .29 of this chapter.

section.heading: Control of Infectious and Contagious Diseases.

para.text: An owner may not knowingly permit an individual to enter the water of a public pool or spa who has:
An infectious or contagious disease that may be transmitted through water;
An open cut, blister, or other lesion; or
Diarrhea.

An owner or operator may not prohibit an individual from entering the water of a public pool or spa if a physician certifies that the individual's condition is not infectious or contagious by waterborne transmission.

section.heading: Injury and Illness Reports.
section.text: A public pool or spa owner shall ensure that:

para.text: An injury, drowning, near drowning, or suction entrapment occurring at a pool or spa that results in death or that requires resuscitation or admission to a hospital is reported to the Secretary within 24 hours of the incident;
A waterborne illness contracted at a pool or spa is reported to the Secretary within 24 hours of the owner's or operator's knowledge of the incident;
A water rescue by aquatic safety personnel is reported to the Secretary every 3 months during operation or at the seasonal closure of the facility, whichever is more frequent; and
The information required in §§A—C of this regulation is recorded on a pool and spa injury and illness report form provided by the Secretary.

section.heading: Disinfection of Swimsuits and Towels.
section.text: An owner shall ensure that a swimsuit or towel furnished to an individual by the owner or operator of a public pool or spa is:

para.text: Washed in a washing machine with laundry detergent in hot water with a temperature of at least 175?F; and
Rinsed in an effective disinfectant or heat dried at 175?F or more for at least 30 minutes after being washed.
An owner who has been granted a variance by the Secretary before February 10, 1997 may continue to operate under that variance.
An owner may request a variance from a requirement of this chapter by submitting a written application that:
Contains specific details of the alternative procedure proposed by the owner;
Specifies the applicable regulation to which the variance pertains;
Explains the reason for the request;
Provides the name and address of the owner;
Provides the name and location of the facility; and
Demonstrates that the alternative procedure proposed:
Meets or produces the intended effect of the regulation for which the variance is requested, and
Maintains the protection of the health and safety of the individuals using the facility at or above the level required by the regulation for which the variance is requested.
Upon consideration of an application for a variance, the Secretary may grant the request for a variance if the:
Applicant has submitted an application in accordance with the provisions of §B of this regulation;
Applicant has complied with all other applicable provisions of this chapter;
Application is justified due to physical limitation of the existing layout of the facility; and
Secretary determines that the alternative procedure proposed by the applicant:
Meets or produces the intended effect of the regulation, and
Maintains the protection of the health and safety of the individuals using the facility at or above the level required by the regulation at issue.

The Secretary shall grant or deny an application for a variance in writing and shall mail the decision to the applicant within 60 days of the date the application for a variance is received by the Department.

If the determination of the Secretary is to deny a variance request that has been made in compliance with the provisions of §B of this regulation, the applicant may file an appeal of the denial in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and shall contact the Secretary within 10 days of receipt of the denial to preserve a right to a hearing.

The owner of a public pool or spa that has a structure, equipment, or appurtenance that is not in compliance with this chapter as determined by the Secretary may submit to the Secretary for approval a compliance schedule for meeting the requirements of this chapter.
The request from an owner for approval of a compliance schedule shall include:
The reason that the noncompliance item cannot be immediately corrected;
The plan for correction of the noncompliance item; and
The time schedule for the correction of the noncompliance item.
The Secretary may approve the compliance schedule if the:
Owner has submitted a written request for approval of a compliance schedule in accordance with §B of this regulation;
Time schedule for the correction of the noncompliance item is accepted by the Secretary; and
Operation of the pool or spa during the time allowed to bring the pool or spa into compliance does not adversely affect the health and safety of the public.
The Secretary may not approve a compliance schedule for a newly constructed pool or spa that has not received construction approval under Regulation .08 of this chapter.
The Secretary shall issue an operating permit or shall refrain from suspending an operating permit to an owner if:
A compliance schedule has been approved by the Secretary for the correction of a noncompliance item;
The owner is following the approved compliance schedule; and
The pool or spa is otherwise in compliance with this chapter.

section.heading: Standardization and Audits of Local Health Departments.

para.text: The Department shall:
Standardize one employee related to the enforcement of this chapter for each local health department to serve as the local standardization officer;
Audit local health department pool and spa programs related to the enforcement of this chapter once every 4 years according to the current audit protocols; and
Provide to the local health department a pool and spa program review final report.

Local health departments shall submit to the Department responses to any deficiencies within the pool and spa program as identified within the pool and spa program review final report within 30 business days of receipt of the report.
